The Act titled "Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 1999" expands S Corporation eligible shareholders to include IRAs. The Act "Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 1999" allows IRAs to be shareholders in S Corporations, with specific provisions for trusts that constitute individual retirement accounts. The Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 1999 allows IRAs to be shareholders in S Corporations. The act includes provisions for trusts that constitute individual retirement accounts, exempting the sale of stock held by a trust in an IRA to the individual for whom the account is established if the sale is made pursuant to an election under section 1362(a). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. The Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 1999 allows IRAs to be shareholders in S Corporations, with provisions for trusts exempting the sale of stock held by a trust in an IRA to the individual for whom the account is established. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. EXCLUSION OF INVESTMENT SECURITIES INCOME FROM PASSIVE INCOME TEST FOR BANK S CORPORATIONS. The amendment excludes certain types of income from the passive investment income definition for banks, bank holding companies, and qualified subchapter S subsidiary banks under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment excludes specific types of income from the passive investment income definition for banks, bank holding companies, and qualified subchapter S subsidiary banks under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN NUMBER OF ELIGIBLE SHAREHOLDERS TO 150. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the number of eligible shareholders from 75 to 150. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. TREATMENT OF QUALIFYING DIRECTOR SHARES. The amendment to Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces the treatment of qualifying director shares, defining them as shares held by an individual solely due to their status as a director of a bank or bank holding company. These shares are not considered a second class of stock, and holding them does not confer shareholder status. The amendment to Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces the treatment of qualifying director shares, which are shares held by an individual solely due to their status as a director of a bank or company. These shares are subject to an agreement requiring disposal upon termination of director status at the same price as acquired. Distributions on these shares are treated as ordinary income for the holder and deductible as an expense for the corporation. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to introduce the treatment of qualifying director shares, which are subject to specific allocation rules for holders. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996, stating that no deductible expense shall be allocated to such income. SEC. 6. The Secretary of the Treasury will modify regulations for S corporation elections made after December 31, 1996, to treat bad debt deductions as built-in losses during the period when a bank recognizes built-in gains from changing its accounting method for bad debts.

SEC. 7. Banks will be included in the 3-year S corporation rule for corporate preference items. SEC. 8 amends the Internal Revenue Code to apply C corporation rules for fringe benefit purposes starting after December 31, 1999. Section 1372 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, regarding partnership rules for fringe benefit purposes, is repealed. Additionally, paragraph (5) of section 162(1) is amended to address health insurance costs for certain S Corporation shareholders. This subsection applies to 2-percent shareholders of an S Corporation, treating their wages as earned income. The text discusses the definition of a "2-percent shareholder" in an S Corporation for tax purposes, with adjustments as prescribed by the Secretary. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing the item related to section 1372 in subchapter S of chapter 1. These amendments will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Expansion of S Corporation eligible shareholders to include family limited partnerships. Expansion of S Corporation eligible shareholders to include family limited partnerships. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow family partnerships to be shareholders in an S corporation if all partners or members are members of one family. Expansion of S Corporation eligible shareholders to include family limited partnerships. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 10. ISSUANCE OF PREFERRED STOCK PERMITTED. Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include the treatment of qualified preferred stock, which is not considered a second class of stock and does not make the holder a shareholder of the corporation. Qualified preferred stock is defined as stock meeting specific requirements and is not disqualified if convertible into other stock. The distribution of qualified preferred stock is treated as ordinary income for the holder and deductible for the corporation. Amendments are made to sections 1361 and 1366 of the Internal Revenue Code regarding qualified preferred stock. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding qualified preferred stock holders, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 11. CONSENT TO ELECTIONS. Section 1362(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to require consent from shareholders holding at least 90 percent of shares for an election. Rules for consent include joint owners and representatives consenting for their shares. The consent requirements for various entities include the personal representative for an estate, a parent or guardian for minors, a trustee for trusts, a trustee for a bankrupt individual's estate, an authorized officer or trustee for organizations described in subsection (c)(6). In the case of a partnership or limited liability company described in subsection (c)(8), all general partners, managers, and members must consent to shares owned by the organization. The amendment to Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code defines the treatment of nonconsenting shareholder stock in an S corporation, stating that such stock is not considered a second class of stock, but rather C corporation stock subject to tax at the highest rate specified in section 11(b). The amendment to Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code addresses nonconsenting shareholder stock in an S corporation. Distributions on such stock are treated as ordinary income for the holder and deductible for the corporation. Additionally, a conforming amendment expands the sections affected by the changes. The amendments made by this section apply to elections in taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 12 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include information returns for qualified Subchapter S subsidiaries. This amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999.
